display.label: Box
display.description: Manage files stored in Box

inputs.comments: The OAuth 2.0 Authorization URL for Box
inputs.label: Authorize URL

inputs.comments: The OAuth 2.0 Token URL for Box
inputs.label: Token URL

inputs.comments: A space-delimited set of one or more scopes. Leave this blank to use your app's configured default scopes.
inputs.label: Scopes

documentation.description:
This component authenticates with Box using OAuth 2.0.
You will need to create a Box OAuth 2.0 app in order to authorize your integration to access your customers' Box accounts.

You can follow along with Box's OAuth 2.0 setup documentation [here](https://developer.box.com/guides/authentication/oauth2/oauth2-setup/). Note:

-   Be sure to select **User Authentication (OAuth 2.0)** when creating a **Custom App**
-   Take note of your **Client ID** and **Client Secret** - you'll enter those in Prismatic in a moment
-   Under **OAuth 2.0 Redirect URI**, enter `https://oauth2.prismatic.io/callback`
-   Under **Application Scopes**, select **Write all files and folders stored in Box**
-   Leave **CORS Domains** blank

When you add a Box step to an integration, a Box OAuth 2.0 connection will be created for you.
Enter the **Client ID** and **Client Secret** that you noted earlier.
You can leave **Scopes** blank to use the **Application Scopes** that you set up previously.
Or, you can pare down scopes as desired (reference Box's [scopes documentation](https://developer.box.com/guides/api-calls/permissions-and-errors/scopes/)).

connections.label: Box Developer Token
connections.comments: Retrieve this from the developer console.

inputs.comments: A short-lived developer token for testing purposes
inputs.label: Developer Token

documentation.description:
A **Developer Token** is a short-lived (60-minute) token that you can use for testing purposes.
A developer token allows you to use the Box API to access your personal Box account only.

:::note
When your integration is ready for production, you'll need an [OAuth 2.0](#box-oauth-20-connection) connection to authenticate your customers' Box accounts.
You can also do your testing with OAuth.
:::

display.label: Raw Request
display.description: Send a raw HTTP request to Box API

inputs.comments: Input the path only (/2.0/folders), The base URL is already included (https://api.box.com). For example, to connect to https://api.box.com/2.0/folders, only /2.0/folders is entered in this field.
inputs.label: URL

inputs.comments: The HTTP method to use.
inputs.label: Method

inputs.comments: The HTTP body payload to send to the URL.
inputs.label: Data

inputs.comments: The Form Data to be sent as a multipart form upload.
inputs.label: Form Data

inputs.comments: File Data to be sent as a multipart form upload.
inputs.label: File Data

inputs.comments: A list of query parameters to send with the request. This is the portion at the end of the URL similar to ?key1=value1&key2=value2.
inputs.label: Query Parameter

inputs.comments: A list of headers to send with the request.
inputs.label: Header

inputs.comments: The type of data you expect in the response. You can request json, text, or binary data.
inputs.label: Response Type

inputs.comments: The maximum time that a client will await a response to its request
inputs.label: Timeout

inputs.comments: Enabling this flag will log out the current request.
inputs.label: Debug Request

inputs.comments: The delay in milliseconds between retries.
inputs.label: Retry Delay (ms)

inputs.comments: If true, retries on all erroneous responses regardless of type.
inputs.label: Retry On All Errors

inputs.comments: The maximum number of retries to attempt.
inputs.label: Max Retry Count

inputs.comments: Specifies whether to use a pre-defined exponential backoff strategy for retries.
inputs.label: Use Exponential Backoff

documentation.description:
[Box](https://www.box.com/) is a file sharing platform that allows teams to collaborate and share files with one another.
The Box component allows you to create, list, fetch, move, or delete files and folders in a customer's Box account.
documentation.dev:
A common integration pattern involves listing files in a file store, and performing a series of actions on the array of files that are returned.
See our [looping over files](quickstarts/looping-over-files.mdx) quickstart for information about how to create a loop over an array of files.
